actual translation: And I said, "I can't take you there, but I can take you into weightlessness into zero-g.

actual translation: I therefore want to encourage public interest in space."

actual translation: And then when you say children, they will pretty quickly agree with you.

actual translation: : We're traveling today with the Minister of Defense of Colombia, head of the army and the head of the police, and we're dropping off 650 laptops today to children who have no television, no telephone and have been in a community cut off from the rest of the world for the past 40 years.

korean: 이 지역에 랩탑 컴퓨터를 제공하는 것은 아이들을 세상과 연결시켜준다는 점에서 중요합니다 40년 전에 정치적 운동으로 시작하여 이 후에 마약까지 관여한 게릴라 조직인 FARC 때문에 아이들은 그동안 세상과 단절되어 있었습니다

actual translation: So, in rough numbers, there are a million laptops.

actual translation: It's the Minister of Defense with whom we're working, not the Minister of Education, because it is seen as a strategic defense issue in the sense of liberating these zones that had been completely closed off, in which the people who had been causing, if you will, 40 years' worth of bombings and kidnappings and assassinations lived.

The reason it is the Minister of Defense and not the Minister of Education is because this is a strategic defense issue with a view to liberalizing this region. That region is completely isolated and inhabited by people who have been bombing, kidnapping and assassinating for 40 years.

actual translation: It's not going to happen, you know, in one year, but it's an important, deeply economic and cultural change that happens through children.

korean: 이 프로젝트는 31개국이 참여하고 있으며, 우루과이를 예로 들면, 절반의 아이들이 이미 이 랩탑 컴퓨터를 보유하고 있습니다. 그리고 2009년 중반에는 우루과이의 모든 아이들은 작은 녹색의 랩탑 컴퓨터를 가지게 될 것입니다

actual translation: Some of the results that go across every single country include teachers saying they have never loved teaching so much, and reading comprehension measured by third parties -- not by us -- skyrockets.
Google translation: Results from each country collected so far include: Teachers say they have never loved teaching before and their reading comprehension skills, assessed by a third party rather than an internal evaluator, have improved dramatically.

actual translation: Probably the most important thing we see is children teaching parents.

korean: 그 아이가 엄마와 함께 온 이유는 6살 아이가 그녀의 엄마에게 글읽는 법과 쓰는 법을 가르쳐왔기 때문입니다
actual translation: And the reason she brought her mother is that this six-year-old child had been teaching her mother how to read and write.
Google translation: The reason the child came with her mother was because the 6-year-old had been teaching her mother how to read and write.

korean: 그녀의 엄마는 초등학교에 가본 적이 없습니다

korean: 이것은 부모와 아이의 역할이 서로 뒤바뀐 것이고, 아이들이 변화의 주체가 되고 있다는 대단히 아름다운 사례입니다
actual translation: And this is such an inversion, and such a wonderful example of children being the agents of change.
Google translation: This is a very beautiful example of the roles of parents and children being reversed and children becoming agents of change.

korean: 사람들은 제게 묻습니다 왜 랩탑 컴퓨터인가요?

actual translation: Laptops are a luxury; it's like giving them iPods. No.

actual translation: The reason you want laptops is that the word is education, not laptop.
Google translation: The reason for giving a laptop computer is the possibility of continuing education.

actual translation: They need to learn learning. And then, just think -- they can have, let's say, 100 books.

korean: 한 마을에서, 100대의 랩탑 컴퓨터가 있고 각각의 랩탑 컴퓨터가 서로 다른 100권의 책을 저장하고 있다면, 그 마을에는 순식간에 10,000권의 책이 있는 것입니다
actual translation: In a village, you have 100 laptops, each with a different set of 100 books, and so that village suddenly has 10,000 books.

korean: 인센티브는 어떨까요?
actual translation: Now, how about incentives?
Google translation: What about incentives?

korean: 언뜻 보면 영리한 방법 같습니다.
actual translation: They seem cleverer.
Google translation: At first glance, it seems like a clever method.

korean: 여러분이 뭔가 일을 해야할 이유가 하나 있다고 해보죠. 제가 여기 이유를 하나 더 드립니다. 논리적으로 봐도 이제 이유가 두개 있으니 그 일을 더 열심히 할 것 같습니다.
actual translation: If you have one reason for doing something and I give you a second reason for doing the same thing, it seems only logical that two reasons are better than one and you're more likely to do it.
Google translation: Let's say you have one reason to do something. Here's one more reason for me. Logically, I think I will work harder now that I have two reasons.

korean: 그렇죠?
actual translation: Right?
Google translation: Right?

korean: 안타깝게도 항상 그런 것은 아닙니다.
actual translation: Well, not always.
Google translation: Unfortunately, this isn't always the case.

korean: 이유가 여러개 있으면 그 이유들끼리 경쟁하는 경우가 있거든요. 서로를 강화시키는 대신에 말입니다. 오히려 일을 덜하죠.
actual translation: Sometimes two reasons to do the same thing seem to compete with one another instead of complimenting, and they make people less likely to do it.
Google translation: If there are multiple reasons, they may compete with each other. Instead of reinforcing each other. Rather, I work less.

korean: 시간이 없으니까 예를 딱 하나만 들게요.
actual translation: I'll just give you one example because time is racing.
Google translation: Since I don't have time, I'll just give you one example.

korean: 15년전 스위스에서 있었던 일입니다. 핵폐기물 매립지를 어디에 지을지 결정하고 있었습니다.
actual translation: In Switzerland, back about 15 years ago, they were trying to decide where to site nuclear waste dumps.
Google translation: This happened 15 years ago in Switzerland. We were deciding where to build a nuclear waste landfill.

korean: 전국규모 투표가 있을 예정이었죠.

Google translation: There was going to be a nationwide vote.

korean: 당시 스위스 심리학자들은 핵폐기물이 어떤건지 잘 아는 사람들을 뽑아다 설문조사를 했습니다.
actual translation: Some psychologists went around and polled citizens who were very well informed.
Google translation: At the time, Swiss psychologists surveyed people who knew what nuclear waste was like.

korean: "당신 동네에 핵폐기물 처리시설을 짓는다고 하면 찬성 하시겠습니까?" 하고 물어봤죠.
actual translation: And they said, "Would you be willing to have a nuclear waste dump in your community?"
Google translation: “If I were to build a nuclear waste disposal facility in your neighborhood, would you agree?” I asked.

korean: 놀랍게도, 50 퍼센트가 "네"라고 대답했습니다.
actual translation: Astonishingly, 50 percent of the citizens said yes.
Google translation: Surprisingly, 50 percent said “yes.”

korean: 그게 위험한지 알면서도 말입니다.
actual translation: They knew it was dangerous.
Google translation: Even though I knew it was dangerous.

korean: 땅값이 떨어지리라는 것도 알고 있었어요.
actual translation: They thought it would reduce their property values.

korean: 어디가 됐든 짓긴 지어야 하는 문제고 스위스 시민으로서 책임이란 것도 있습니다.
actual translation: But it had to go somewhere and they had responsibilities as citizens.
Google translation: No matter where you go, you have to build something, and as a Swiss citizen, you also have a responsibility.

korean: 심리들은 이번엔 다른 사람들을 상대로 약간 다른 질문을 해봤습니다.
actual translation: The psychologists asked other people a slightly different question.
Google translation: The researchers asked slightly different questions, this time to different people.

korean: "1년에 6주치 봉급을 더 준다면 당신 동네에 핵폐기물 처리시설을 짓는 것에 찬성 하시겠습니까?"
actual translation: They said, "If we paid you six weeks' salary every year would you be willing to have a nuclear waste dump in your community?"
Google translation: “Would you agree to building a nuclear waste disposal facility in your neighborhood if you were paid six weeks more salary a year?”

korean: 동기가 두개죠. 첫째 내 책임이고, 둘째로 돈도 받습니다.

Google translation: There are two motivations. Firstly, it is my responsibility, and secondly, I get paid.

korean: 앞선 예에서 50%가 "네"라고 했던 것에 반해, 이번 경우엔 "네"가 25퍼센트에 지나지 않았어요.
actual translation: Instead of 50 percent saying yes, 25 percent said yes.

actual translation: What happens is that the second this introduction of incentive gets us so that instead of asking, "What is my responsibility?"
Google translation: Because in the second question, the question changed as incentives came into play. The question “What are my responsibilities?”

korean: "어떤 쪽이 이득이지?"라는 질문으로 바뀌어 버린거죠.

korean: 인센티브가 더이상 안먹힐때 CEO가 두둑한 보너스라는 단기적인 이득에 눈이 멀어 회사의 장기적인 건전성을 무시할 때, 돌아오는 반응은 늘 같습니다.

korean: 좀더 '똑똑한' 인센티브 제도를 만들자!
actual translation: Get smarter incentives.
Google translation: Let’s create a more ‘smart’ incentive system!

korean: 하지만 현실은 이겁니다. 우리는 결코 '충분히 똑똑한' 인센티브를 만들 수 없습니다.
actual translation: The truth is that there are no incentives that you can devise that are ever going to be smart enough.

korean: 인센티브란 언제나 고의에 의해 악용될 수 있으니까요.
actual translation: Any incentive system can be subverted by bad will.

actual translation: But excessive reliance on incentives demoralizes professional activity in two senses of that word.
Google translation: However, relying too much on incentives has two negative effects on our work as professionals.

korean: 그 일을 하는 사람의 사기를 낮추고, 결과적으로 일 자체의 도덕성도 잃게 만듭니다.
actual translation: It causes people who engage in that activity to lose morale and it causes the activity itself to lose morality.

korean: 대통령 취임식 전에 오바마가 말했습니다. "그것이 이득인지를 묻기 전에, 그것이 옳은 일인지를 물어야 한다"고요. 직업생활에서 자발적 도덕성이 붕괴되면 사람들은 점점 인센티브에 의존적이됩니다. 중독되는거죠. 더이상 "이게 옳은 일인지"를 묻지 않아요.
actual translation: Barack Obama said, before he was inaugurated, "We must ask not just 'Is it profitable?' but 'Is it right?'" And when professions are demoralized, everyone in them becomes dependent on -- addicted to -- incentives and they stop asking "Is it right?"
Google translation: Obama said before the presidential inauguration. “Before asking whether it is beneficial, you must ask whether it is the right thing to do.” As voluntary morality breaks down in professional life, people become increasingly incentive-dependent. You become addicted. I no longer ask “Is this the right thing to do?”

korean: 의약업계에서는 이게 이미 현실입니다.

korean: ("별거 아니긴 한데 좀 지켜보죠. 혹시 나중에 소송으로 번질수도 있으니까요") 비즈니스 세계에서는 이게 공공연연한 현실입니다.

korean: "벤담, 미안하지만 해고네. 우리 회사도 시장 경쟁력을 유지하려면 자네같은 사람보단 시키는 것만 할 줄 아는 멍청한 사람이 필요하거든.") ("난 지금 호가 십분의 일 값에 내 영혼을 팔아버렸지.") 이런 방식으로 일하고 싶은 사람은 아무도 없습니다. 당연하죠.
actual translation: ("In order to remain competitive in today's marketplace, I'm afraid we're going to have to replace you with a sleezeball.") ("I sold my soul for about a tenth of what the damn things are going for now.") It is obvious that this is not the way people want to do their work.

korean: 어떡할까요?
actual translation: So what can we do?

actual translation: A few sources we ought to try to re-moralize work.
Google translation: There are some hopeful facts. We need to bring ethics and morals back to the workplace.

korean: 윤리 교육을 강화한다.
actual translation: One way not to teach more ethics courses.
Google translation: Strengthen ethics education.

korean: 사람과 사람 사이의 도리에 관한 문제는 종이쪼가리에 적고 나서 악수하고 서명한다고 되는 게 아닙니다. 인간성에 관한 걸 그냥 도매급으로 문서로 박제한다고 해서 장땡이 아닌거죠.
actual translation: There is no better way to show people that you're not serious than to tie up everything you have to say about ethics into a little package with a bow and consign it to the margins as an ethics course.
Google translation: Issues regarding duties between people cannot be resolved by writing them down on a piece of paper and then shaking hands and signing. Just because it stuffs things about humanity into documents at wholesale level doesn't mean it's a good idea.

korean: 그럼 무슨 방법이 있을까요?

Google translation: People are inspired by heroes with such humanity.

actual translation: But we learn that with sophistication comes the understanding that you can't acknowledge that you have moral heroes.
Google translation: Of course, as we live, we learn that it is not as easy as it sounds. Even if there is such a person, it is not easy to recognize him.

korean: 그래도 그냥 알아 주세요.

korean: 그런 사람이 주위에 있다는걸 자랑스러워 하세요.

korean: 인정해 주세요.

korean: 이게 우리가 할 수 있는 일의 하납니다.

korean: 여러분들중에 몇분이나 이걸 기억하실지 모르겠군요. 15년전에 아론 푸어스타인이라는 인간성의 제왕(!?)이 있었죠. 메사추세츠에 있는 몰든 밀의 사장이었어요. 나중에 폴라텍이라는 회사를 만들었죠. 한번은 그의 공장에 불이 났습니다.
actual translation: I don't know how many of you another moral hero, 15 years ago, Aaron Feuerstein, who was the head of Malden Mills in Massachusetts -- they made Polartec -- The factory burned down.
Google translation: I don't know how many of you will remember this. 15 years ago, there was a king(!?) of humanity named Aaron Fuerstein. He was the president of Malden Mill in Massachusetts. Later, I created a company called Polartec. One time his factory caught fire.

korean: 그랬는데도 3천명의 직원중 한명도 빠짐없이 죄다 월급을 지급했죠.
actual translation: 3,000 employees. He kept every one of them on the payroll.

korean: 왜? 직원들 입장에서는 엄청난 재앙이거든요. 월급을 안줬으면 3천명이 사는 그 "동네"입장에서도 재앙이었을거고요.
actual translation: Why? Because it would have been a disaster for them and for the community if he had let them go.
Google translation: why? It's a huge disaster for the employees. If salaries had not been paid, it would have been a disaster for the “neighborhood” where 3,000 people live.

korean: "월스트릿 입장에서 보면 우리회사 평가가치가 많이 떨어졌을겁니다. 하지만 저는 이게 더 가치있는 일인거 같네요. 우린 잘 하고 있습니다."
actual translation: "Maybe on paper our company is worth less to Wall Street, but I can tell you it's worth more. We're doing fine."
Google translation: “From Wall Street’s perspective, our company’s valuation has probably fallen a lot. But I think this is more valuable. We’re doing well.”

actual translation: Just at this TED we heard talks from several moral heroes.

korean: 한명은 레이 앤더슨입니다. 악의 소굴에서 벌어지는 사업에 대해 흔적이 하나도 안남는 깨끗한 사업으로 바꿔놨으니까요.
actual translation: One was Ray Anderson, who turned -- -- turned, you know, a part of the evil empire into a zero-footprint, or almost zero-footprint business.

korean: 왜냐고요? 그게 맞는 일이니까요.
actual translation: Why? Because it was the right thing to do.

korean: 그는 기대치도 않았던 덤으로 돈도 더 많이 벌게 생겼습니다.
actual translation: And a bonus he's discovering is he's actually going to make even more money.

korean: 직원들도 많이 자극 받고 있습니다.
actual translation: His employees are inspired by the effort.

korean: 왜냐구요? 자신이 맞다고 생각하는 일을 하는 사람은 행복하거든요.
actual translation: Why? Because there happy to be doing something that's the right thing to do.
Google translation: Why? People who do what they think is right are happy.

korean: 어제 윌리 스미츠가 인도네시아에 숲을 다시 만드는 일에 대해 얘기했었죠.
actual translation: Yesterday we heard Willie Smits talk about re-foresting in Indonesia.

korean: 옳은 일을 하는데 "의지"가 필요했으니까요.
actual translation: Because it took the will to do the right thing.

korean: 겉으로보면 별것 아닌거 같아도 대단히 많은 기술과 노력이 필요합니다.
actual translation: God knows it took a huge amount of technical skill.

korean: 윌리의 팀이 그 일을 추진하는데 알아야 할 게 그렇게 많을 줄은 저도차도 몰랐습니다. 깜짝 놀랐어요.
actual translation: I'm boggled at how much he and his associates needed to know in order to plot this out.
Google translation: I had no idea that Willy's team would need to know so much to move forward with the project. I was surprised.

korean: 윌리도 강조했다시피, 이 일을 가능하게 만드는 데 가장 중요한 것은 그 동네의 사람을 "제대로 아는 것"이었습니다.
actual translation: But most important to make it work -- and he emphasized this -- is that it took knowing the people in the communities.

korean: 현지 사람들과의 좋은 관계계를 통해 얻는 도움 없이는 실패했을테니까요.
actual translation: Unless the people you're working with are behind you, this will fail.

korean: 현지 사람들을 자기 편으로 만드는 공식같은 건 없습니다. 다른 사회에는 다른 사람들이 제각기 삶을 운영하는 저각기 다른 방식이라는게 있으니까요.
actual translation: And there isn't a formula to tell you how to get the people behind you, because different people in different communities organize their lives in different ways.

actual translation: So there's a lot here at TED, and at other places, to celebrate.

korean: 여러분이 무슨 엄청나게 큰 대인배 성인군자가 될 필요는 없어요.
actual translation: And you don't have to be a mega-hero.

korean: 생활속의 실천가로서 우리 모두는 크든 작든 생활속의 실천가로서 영웅이 되기 위해 노력해야 합니다.

korean: 긍정 감정을 많이 경험하고, 이를 증폭하는 솜씨가 있으면 갖게 되는 삶입니다.
actual translation: This is a life in which you have as much positive emotion as you possibly can, and the skills to amplify it.
Google translation: This is the life you can have if you experience a lot of positive emotions and have the skill to amplify them.

korean: 두번째는 관여하는 삶입니다. 일하고, 애 키우고, 사랑하고, 여가를 즐길 때 여러분의 시간이 멈춥니다.
actual translation: The second is a life of engagement -- a life in your work, your parenting, your love, your leisure, time stops for you.
Google translation: The second is a life of involvement. Time stands still for you as you work, raise children, love, and enjoy leisure.

korean: 이것이 바로 아리스토텔레스가 이야기하던 것입니다.
actual translation: That's what Aristotle was talking about.
Google translation: This is exactly what Aristotle was talking about.

korean: 그리고 세번째로, 의미있는 삶입니다.
actual translation: And third, the meaningful life.
Google translation: And thirdly, a meaningful life.

korean: 그럼 이러한 삶 각각에 대해 조금 더 이야기하고 이에 대해 무엇을 알고 있는지 이야기하겠습니다.
actual translation: So I want to say a little bit about each of those lives and what we know about them.
Google translation: So let me tell you a little more about each of these lives and what we know about them.

korean: 첫번째 삶은 즐거운 삶입니다. 그것은 최선을 다하면 간단하게 찾을 수 있고 즐거움을 경험한 만큼 가질 수 있습니다. 긍정 감정을 경험한 만큼 얻을 수 있습니다. 그리고 음미, 유념 등 즐거움을 증폭시키고, 오래도록 즐기는 기술을 배울수 있습니다.
actual translation: The first life is the pleasant life and it's simply, as best we can find it, it's having as many of the pleasures as you can, as much positive emotion as you can, and learning the skills -- savoring, mindfulness -- that amplify them, that stretch them over time and space.
Google translation: The first life is a joyful life. It is simple to find if you do your best and you can have as much pleasure as you experience. The more positive emotions you experience, the more you will gain. You can also learn skills such as savoring and mindfully amplifying your enjoyment and enjoying it for a long time.

korean: 그리나 즐거운 삶에는 세가지 단점이 있습니다. 이는 긍정 심리학이 행복학이 아니고, 행복학에서 머물지 않는 이유이기도 합니다.
actual translation: But the pleasant life has three drawbacks, and it's why positive psychology is not happy-ology and why it doesn't end here.
Google translation: However, there are three downsides to a happy life. This is also the reason why positive psychology is not the study of happiness and does not remain within the study of happiness.

korean: 첫 번째 단점은 즐거운 삶, 긍정적인 감정의 경험은 유전적이라는 사실입니다. 약 50퍼센트가 유전적인 것이고 사실 잘 바꿔지지 않습니다.
actual translation: The first drawback is that it turns out the pleasant life, your experience of positive emotion, is heritable, about 50 percent heritable, and, in fact, not very modifiable.
Google translation: The first drawback is that a joyful life and the experience of positive emotions are genetic. About 50 percent of it is genetic and in fact rarely changes.

korean: 그래서 매튜와 저, 그리고 다른 사람들이 알고 있는 삶에서 긍정적인 감정을 늘리는 다양한 비결들은 15퍼센트에서 20퍼센트 더 얻을 수 있는 비결입니다.
actual translation: So the different tricks that Matthieu [Ricard] and I and others know about increasing the amount of positive emotion in your life are 15 to 20 percent tricks, getting more of it.
Google translation: So the various secrets that Matthew and I and others know about increasing positive emotions in your life are the secrets to getting 15 to 20 percent more.

korean: 두번째로 긍정적인 감정은 익숙해집니다. 정말 빠르게 익숙해집니다.
actual translation: Second is that positive emotion habituates. It habituates rapidly, indeed.
Google translation: Second, positive emotions become habitual. You get used to it really quickly.

korean: 프렌치 바닐라 아이스크림과 비슷합니다. 첫번째 맛은 100퍼센트죠. 그런데 6번째 맛을 보는 순간 그 맛은 사라져버립니다.
actual translation: It's all like French vanilla ice cream, the first taste is a 100 percent; by the time you're down to the sixth taste, it's gone.
Google translation: It's similar to French vanilla ice cream. The first taste is 100 percent. But the moment you taste it for the 6th time, the taste disappears.

korean: 말씀드렸듯이 바뀔 수 있는 것이 아닙니다.
actual translation: And, as I said, it's not particularly malleable.
Google translation: As I said, it's not something that can be changed.

korean: 이제 두 번째 삶에 대해 이야기해봅시다.
actual translation: And this leads to the second life.
Google translation: Now let's talk about second life.

korean: 제 친구인 렌에 대해 말씀드려야할 것 같네요 왜 긍정심리학이 긍정적인 감정 이상의 것이고 즐거움을 만들어가는 것 이상의 것인지 말씀드리겠습니다.
actual translation: And I have to tell you about my friend, Len, to talk about why positive psychology is more than positive emotion, more than building pleasure.
Google translation: I guess I should tell you about my friend Len and why positive psychology is more than positive emotions and more than creating joy.

korean: 렌은 30살이 되기까지, 인생의 3가지 큰 무대 중 2 곳에 서게 됩니다. 렌은 크게 성공했습니다. 첫번째 무대는 일이었죠.
actual translation: In two of the three great arenas of life, by the time Len was 30, Len was enormously successful. The first arena was work.
Google translation: Until Ren turns 30, he will stand on two of the three major stages of his life. Wren was a huge success. The first stage was work.

korean: 20살이 됐을 때, 그는 옵션 트레이더 였습니다.
actual translation: By the time he was 20, he was an options trader.
Google translation: By the age of 20, he was an options trader.

korean: 25살에 백만장자가 되었습니다. 옵션 트레이딩 회사의 사장이 되었죠.
actual translation: By the time he was 25, he was a multimillionaire and the head of an options trading company.
Google translation: I became a millionaire at the age of 25. I became the president of an options trading company.

korean: 두번째가 놀이입니다. 그는 전국 브리지대회 챔피언입니다.
actual translation: Second, in play -- he's a national champion bridge player.
Google translation: The second is play. He is a national bridge champion.

korean: 그러나 세번 째 인생의 무대인 사랑에서 렌은 지독하게 실패하였습니다.
actual translation: But in the third great arena of life, love, Len is an abysmal failure.
Google translation: However, in the third stage of his life, love, Ren failed terribly.

korean: 그 원인은 렌이 차가운 사람이었기 때문입니다.
actual translation: And the reason he was, was that Len is a cold fish.
Google translation: The reason was because Ren was a cold person.

korean: 렌은 내향적입니다.
actual translation: Len is an introvert.
Google translation: Len is an introvert.

korean: 렌이 데이트 할 때 미국 여성들은 이런 말을 했죠. 당신은 재미없어요. 긍정 감정이 없어요. 떠나 버립니다.
actual translation: American women said to Len, when he dated them, "You're no fun. You don't have positive emotion. Get lost."
Google translation: When Ren was dating, American women said this. You are no fun. There are no positive emotions. leaves.

korean: 렌은 파크 애비뉴의 정신분석가를 찾아갈 수 있을 만큼 부유했습니다. 5년 동안 그 분석가는 렌이 성적으로 충격을 받아 긍정감정을 자신 안에 가두는지에 초점을 맞췄습니다.
actual translation: And Len was wealthy enough to be able to afford a Park Avenue psychoanalyst, who for five years tried to find the sexual trauma that had somehow locked positive emotion inside of him.
Google translation: Wren was wealthy enough to visit a psychoanalyst on Park Avenue. For five years, the analyst focused on whether Len was so sexually traumatized that he locked away his positive emotions.

korean: 그러나 결국 성적인 정신적 외상은 없다고 밝혀졌습니다.
actual translation: But it turned out there wasn't any sexual trauma.
Google translation: But in the end, it turned out that there was no sexual trauma.

korean: 밝혀진 것은 렌이 롱 아일랜드에서 자랐으며 그는 축구하고, 축구 경기를 보고, 브리지 게임을 즐겼다는 것입니다. 렌은 소위 긍정적 감정 상태의 하위 5%에 속하는 사람입니다.
actual translation: It turned out that -- Len grew up in Long Island and he played football and watched football, and played bridge -- Len is in the bottom five percent of what we call positive affectivities.
Google translation: It turns out that Len grew up on Long Island and he enjoyed playing soccer, watching soccer games, and playing bridge. Len is in the bottom 5% of so-called positive emotional states.

korean: 그렇다면 렌은 불행한가요? 저는 아니라고 대답하고 싶습니다.
actual translation: The question is, is Len unhappy? And I want to say not.
Google translation: So is Ren unhappy? I would like to say no.

korean: 심리학에서 긍정적 감정 상태의 하위 50퍼센트의 사람에 대해 이야기하는 것과는 상반되는 것입니다. 렌은 가장 행복한 사람 중 한 명이라고 생각합니다.
actual translation: Contrary to what psychology told us about the bottom 50 percent of the human race in positive affectivity, I think Len is one of the happiest people I know.
Google translation: This is contrary to what psychology says about people being in the bottom 50 percent of positive emotional states. I think Len is one of the happiest people around.

korean: 그는 불행이라는 지옥에 굴하지 않습니다. 렌은 여러분과 마찬가지로 몰입에 엄청나게 능숙하기 때문입니다.
actual translation: He's not consigned to the hell of unhappiness and that's because Len, like most of you, is enormously capable of flow.
Google translation: He does not succumb to the hell of misfortune. Because Ren, like you, is incredibly good at immersion.

korean: 그가 아침 9시 30분, 미국 증권 거래소로 걸어 들어가면 시간은 그를 위해 멈춥니다. 마감 벨이 울릴 때까지 멈추죠.
actual translation: When he walks onto the floor of the American Exchange at 9:30 in the morning, time stops for him. And it stops till the closing bell.
Google translation: When he walks into the American Stock Exchange at 9:30 in the morning, time stands still for him. We stop until the closing bell rings.

korean: 경기에서 첫째 카드가 나올 때 10일 후 토너먼트가 끝날 때까지 시간은 렌을 위해 멈춥니다.
actual translation: When the first card is played, until 10 days later, the tournament is over, time stops for Len.
Google translation: When the first card is drawn in a match, time stands still for Rennes until the end of the tournament 10 days later.

korean: 이것이 바로 마이크 칙센트미하이가 이야기하고 있는 것입니다. 몰입, 이는 즐거움과 매우 중요한 측면에서 구별이 됩니다.
actual translation: And this is indeed what Mike Csikszentmihalyi has been talking about, about flow. And it's distinct from pleasure in a very important way.
Google translation: This is what Mike Csikszentmihalyi is talking about. Flow, which is distinct from enjoyment in a very important way.

korean: 즐거움은 원초적이라, 그 느낌을 압니다. 생각과 감정입니다.
actual translation: Pleasure has you know it's happening. It's thought and feeling.
Google translation: Joy is primal, I know the feeling. Thoughts and emotions.

korean: 그러나 어제 마이크가 말한 몰입할 때 다른 아무것도 느낄 수 없습니다.
actual translation: But what Mike told you yesterday -- during flow, you can't feel anything.
Google translation: But as Mike said yesterday, when you're immersed, you can't feel anything else.

korean: 여러분은 음악과 하나가 됩니다. 시간이 멈춥니다.
actual translation: You're one with the music. Time stops.
Google translation: You become one with the music. Time stops.

korean: 여러분은 고도로 집중합니다.
actual translation: You have intense concentration.
Google translation: You are highly focused.

korean: 그리고 이것이 우리가 훌륭한 삶이라고 생각하는 진정한 특성입니다.
actual translation: And this is indeed the characteristic of what we think of as the good life.
Google translation: And these are the true characteristics of what we consider a good life.

korean: 여기엔 비결이 있는데, 바로 여러분의 최대 강점이 무엇인지 아는 것이죠.
actual translation: And we think there's a recipe for it, and it's knowing what your highest strengths are.
Google translation: Here's the secret: know what your greatest strengths are.

korean: 한가지 더, 효과적인 테스트가 있습니다. 여러분의 5가지 강점을 알려주는 테스트입니다.
actual translation: And again, there's a valid test of what your five highest strengths are.
Google translation: One more thing, there is an effective test. This is a test that tells you your five strengths.

korean: 이것들을 마음껏 활용해 여러분의 삶을 다시 만들어 가기 바랍니다.
actual translation: And then re-crafting your life to use them as much as you possibly can.
Google translation: I hope you use these to your heart's content and start rebuilding your life.

korean: 여러분의 일과 사랑을 다시 만들어보세요 여러분의 놀이, 우정, 양육도 다시 만들어보세요
actual translation: Re-crafting your work, your love, your play, your friendship, your parenting.
Google translation: Recreate your work, your love, your play, your friendships, your parenting.

korean: 제 동료 중 소매점에서 물건 담는 일을 했던 친구가 있습니다.
actual translation: Just one example. One person I worked with was a bagger at Genuardi's.
Google translation: I have a friend who worked as a stockist at a retail store.

korean: 그 일을 싫어했죠.
actual translation: Hated the job.
Google translation: I hated that job.

korean: 그녀는 대학 시절 내내 일을 했었습니다.
actual translation: She's working her way through college.
Google translation: She worked throughout college.

korean: 그녀의 최대 강점은 사회 지능이었습니다. 그녀는 물건 담는 일을 다시 만들어, 고객들이 그녀와 만남을 하루 중 가장 흥미로운 일로 여기도록 했습니다..
actual translation: Her highest strength was social intelligence, so she re-crafted bagging to make the encounter with her the social highlight of every customer's day.
Google translation: Her greatest strength was her social intelligence. She reinvented the task of stocking, making it so that customers would find meeting her the most exciting part of their day.

korean: 지금 그녀는 분명 실패했습니다.
actual translation: Now obviously she failed.
Google translation: Now she has clearly failed.

korean: 그러나 그녀가 했던 것은 자신의 최대 강점을 집어내, 일을 다시 만들어, 최대한 활용했던 것입니다.
actual translation: But what she did was to take her highest strengths, and re-craft work to use them as much as possible.
Google translation: But what she did was take her greatest strengths, rework them, and make the most of them.

korean: 그것을 통해 얻는 것은 미소짓기가 아닙니다.
actual translation: What you get out of that is not smiley-ness.
Google translation: What you get from it is not a smile.

korean: 여러분은 데비 레이놀드처럼 생기지 않았습니다.
actual translation: You don't look like Debbie Reynolds.

korean: 그다지 낄낄거리지 않습니다. 여러분은 더 열중합니다.
actual translation: You don't giggle a lot. What you get is more absorption.
Google translation: Not much of a giggle. You are more engaged.

korean: 그것이 두번째 길입니다. 첫번째 길은 긍정적인 감정이죠.
actual translation: So, that's the second path. The first path, positive emotion.
Google translation: That is the second way. The first path is positive emotions.

korean: 두번째 길은 행복한 몰입입니다.
actual translation: The second path is eudaimonian flow.
Google translation: The second path is happy immersion.

korean: 그리고 세번째 길은 의미입니다.
actual translation: And the third path is meaning.
Google translation: And the third way is meaning.

korean: 전통적으로 가장 숭엄한 행복입니다
actual translation: This is the most venerable of the happinesses, traditionally.
Google translation: Traditionally, it is the most sublime happiness.

korean: 이런 관점에서 의미는 행복과 매우 비슷한데, 의미는 최대 강점을 아는 것과, 그 강점을 사용해 여러분보다 더 큰 무엇인가에 속해, 봉사하는 것으로 이뤄져 있습니다.
actual translation: And meaning, in this view, consists of -- very parallel to eudaimonia -- it consists of knowing what your highest strengths are, and using them to belong to and in the service of something larger than you are.
Google translation: In this respect, meaning is very similar to happiness: it consists of knowing your greatest strengths and using those strengths to belong and serve something bigger than yourself.

korean: 제가 언급한 세가지 삶은, 즐거운 삶, 훌륭한 삶, 의미있는 삶이며 현재 사람들은 이 문제에 대해 열심히 연구하고 있습니다. 영속적으로 이러한 삶을 변화시키는 것이 있을까요?
actual translation: I mentioned that for all three kinds of lives, the pleasant life, the good life, the meaningful life, people are now hard at work on the question, are there things that lastingly change those lives?
Google translation: The three lives I mentioned are the joyful life, the good life, and the meaningful life, and people are currently working hard on these issues. Is there anything that will permanently change these lives?

korean: 대답은 '있다' 인 것 같습니다. 그럼 제가 몇가지 사례를 말씀드리겠습니다.
actual translation: And the answer seems to be yes. And I'll just give you some samples of it.
Google translation: The answer seems to be yes. So let me tell you some examples.

korean: 엄격한 방법으로 진행이 되고 있습니다.
actual translation: It's being done in a rigorous manner.
Google translation: It is being carried out in a strict manner.

korean: 약물의 효과를 측정하는 것과 같은 방식으로 진행되고 있습니다.
actual translation: It's being done in the same way that we test drugs to see what really works.
Google translation: It's happening in the same way that you measure the effectiveness of a drug.

korean: 우리는 무작위로 할당하고, 위약 통제조건도 넣고, 다양한 방식의 개입에 장기연구를 수행했습니다.
actual translation: So we do random assignment, placebo controlled, long-term studies of different interventions.
Google translation: We conducted long-term studies with random assignment, placebo controls, and different types of interventions.

korean: 효과가 있다고 판명된 개입 몇가지 소개하겠습니다. 우리가 즐거운 삶을 사람들에게 가르쳐줄 때, 삶에서 더 많은 즐거움을 갖는 방법을 알려줄 때, 참가자들의 과제는 유념하고, 음미하는 기술을 습득하고 아름다운 날을 설계하는 과제입니다.
actual translation: And just to sample the kind of interventions that we find have an effect, when we teach people about the pleasant life, how to have more pleasure in your life, one of your assignments is to take the mindfulness skills, the savoring skills, and you're assigned to design a beautiful day.
Google translation: Here are a few interventions that have been shown to be effective. When we teach people about joyful living, when we teach them how to have more joy in life, the challenge for participants is to master the skills of mindfulness, savoring, and planning beautiful days.

korean: 다음 토요일, 하루를 내, 여러분 스스로 아름다운 날을 설계해 보십시오. 그리고 음미와 유념을 이용해, 즐거움을 증진시켜 보십시오.
actual translation: Next Saturday, set a day aside, design yourself a beautiful day, and use savoring and mindfulness to enhance those pleasures.
Google translation: Next Saturday, take a day to plan a beautiful day for yourself. And use savoring and mindfulness to enhance your enjoyment.

korean: 즐거운 삶이 증진된다는 것을 이 방법으로 보여줄 수 있습니다.
actual translation: And we can show in that way that the pleasant life is enhanced.
Google translation: This is how you can show that a joyful life is promoted.

korean: 감사 방문. 여러분 모두 지금 저와 함께 한번 해보도록 하죠.
actual translation: Gratitude visit. I want you all to do this with me now, if you would.
Google translation: Thanks for visiting. Let's all try it with me now.

korean: 눈을 감으십시오.
actual translation: Close your eyes.
Google translation: Close your eyes.

korean: 여러분의 삶에서 아주 중요한 역할을 한 사람을 떠올려 보십시오. 여러분의 삶을 좋은 방향으로 바꾼 사람 말입니다. 감사의 표시를 제대로 하지 못했던 분 말입니다.
actual translation: I'd like you to remember someone who did something enormously important that changed your life in a good direction, and who you never properly thanked.

actual translation: Your assignment, when you're learning the gratitude visit, is to write a 300-word testimonial to that person, call them on the phone in Phoenix, ask if you can visit, don't tell them why, show up at their door, you read the testimonial -- everyone weeps when this happens.

actual translation: And fun versus philanthropy.

To what extent does the pursuit of pleasure, the pursuit of positive emotions, the pursuit of an enjoyable life, the pursuit of involvement, making time stop for you, and the pursuit of meaning contribute to life satisfaction?

actual translation: Things that were thought impossible just a few years ago can actually be measured now.

korean: 하지만 사실 배우 로빈 윌리엄스는 이미 몇 년 전에 비슷한 내용의 말을 한적이 있죠.
actual translation: This was figured out by Robin Williams a few years before the rest of us.
Google translation: But in fact, actor Robin Williams already said something similar a few years ago.

korean: 새로운 뇌 세포를 만들기 위해 여러분이 할 수 있는 있는 일에는 여러가지가 있습니다.
actual translation: Now, there's some things that you can do to make your brain grow new brain cells.
Google translation: There are many things you can do to create new brain cells.

korean: 제 마음에 가장 와닿는 것은 초콜릿, 차, 블루베리, 소량의 알코올 섭취, 스트레스 관리, 그리고 마리화나에서 발견되는 카나비노이드이죠.
actual translation: Some of my favorite things, like chocolate and tea, blueberries, alcohol in moderation, stress management and cannabinoids found in marijuana.
Google translation: The ones that resonate most with me are chocolate, tea, blueberries, small amounts of alcohol, stress management, and the cannabinoids found in marijuana.

korean: 직접 해본건 아니고 그냥 그렇다고 하더군요.
actual translation: I'm just the messenger.
Google translation: I haven't tried it myself, but I just said it was like that.

korean: 무슨 얘기를 하고 있었죠?
actual translation: What were we just talking about?
Google translation: What were you talking about?

korean: 반면에, 뇌 세포를 죽이는 활동들도 있습니다.
actual translation: And other things that can make it worse, that can cause you to lose brain cells.
Google translation: On the other hand, there are also activities that kill brain cells.

korean: 주로 거론되는 것에는 포화 지방, 설탕, 니코틴, 아편제, 코카인, 알코올 과다 섭취, 그리고 만성 스트레스가 있습니다.
actual translation: The usual suspects, like saturated fat and sugar, nicotine, opiates, cocaine, too much alcohol and chronic stress.
Google translation: Common ones mentioned include excessive consumption of saturated fat, sugar, nicotine, opiates, cocaine, alcohol, and chronic stress.

korean: 일상생활에 변화를 주면 여러분의 피부는 혈액을 더 많이 공급 받게 됩니다. 결과적으로 피부 주름이 그만큼 적어지고 나이를 적게 먹은 것처럼 보이죠.
actual translation: Your skin gets more blood flow when you change your lifestyle, so you age less quickly. Your skin doesn't wrinkle as much.
Google translation: Making changes to your daily routine will help your skin receive more blood. As a result, there are fewer wrinkles on your skin and you look younger.

korean: 피부 뿐만 아니라 여러분의 심장에도 혈액 공급이 많아집니다.
actual translation: Your heart gets more blood flow.
Google translation: Blood supply increases not only to the skin but also to your heart.

korean: 때문에 실제로 심장 질환을 되돌릴 수도 있습니다.
actual translation: We've shown that you can actually reverse heart disease.
Google translation: Because of this, it may actually reverse heart disease.

korean: 왼쪽 위에 보시는 동맥경화는 불과 1년 뒤 눈에 쉽게 띌 정도로 상태가 호전됩니다.
actual translation: That these clogged arteries that you see on the upper left, after only a year become measurably less clogged.
Google translation: The arteriosclerosis seen in the upper left improves to a point where it is easily noticeable after just one year.

korean: 왼쪽 아래 PET 스캔을 보시면 파란색은 혈액 공급이 없다는 것을 의미합니다.
actual translation: And the cardiac PET scan shown on the lower left, the blue means no blood flow.
Google translation: If you look at the PET scan below left, the blue color means there is no blood supply.

korean: 불과 1년 뒤 최대 혈액 공급을 뜻하는 주황색과 하얀색이 훨씬 많아졌죠.
actual translation: A year later -- orange and white is maximum blood flow.
Google translation: Just a year later, there was a lot more orange and white, signifying maximum blood supply.

korean: 일상생활의 변화만으로도 전립선암 혹은 그 연장선에 있는 유방암의 발달을 멈추고 상태를 호전시킬 수 있다는 것을 알 수 있었습니다.
actual translation: We've shown you may be able to stop and reverse the progression of early prostate cancer and, by extension, breast cancer, simply by making these changes.
Google translation: I found out that just by changing my daily life, I could stop the development of prostate cancer or its extension, breast cancer, and improve the condition.

korean: 실험실에서 암 세포를 배양한 결과 이런 변화를 준 실험군의 70%는 배양이 억제된 반면 비교군은 단지 9%만이 배양이 억제 됐습니다.
actual translation: We've found that tumor growth in vitro was inhibited 70 percent in the group that made these changes, whereas only nine percent in the comparison group.
Google translation: As a result of cultivating cancer cells in the laboratory, 70% of the experimental group that made these changes were inhibited in culture, while only 9% of the comparison group was inhibited.

korean: 이 차이는 굉장히 큰 것입니다.
actual translation: These differences were highly significant.
Google translation: This difference is very big.

korean: 여러분의 성기도 혈액을 더 많이 공급 받아 성 능력이 향상됩니다.
actual translation: Even your sexual organs get more blood flow, so you increase sexual potency.
Google translation: Your sexual organs will also receive more blood, which will improve your sexual performance.

korean: 여태까지 가장 효과적이었던 금연 광고 중 하나는 보건부가 내놓은 것이었는데 동맥경화를 유발하는 니코틴 성분이 심장 질환과 중풍 뿐만 아니라 발기 부전의 원인이 된다는 점을 보여줬었습니다.
actual translation: One of the most effective anti-smoking ads was done by the Department of Health Services, showing that nicotine, which constricts your arteries, can cause a heart attack or a stroke, but it also causes impotence.
Google translation: One of the most effective anti-smoking advertisements ever was from the Ministry of Health, which showed that nicotine, which causes arteriosclerosis, not only causes heart disease and stroke, but also erectile dysfunction.

korean: 실제로 흡연자의 절반 정도가 발기 부전을 겪고 있습니다.
actual translation: Half of guys who smoke are impotent.
Google translation: In fact, about half of smokers suffer from erectile dysfunction.

korean: 확실히 효과적인 광고죠.
actual translation: How sexy is that?
Google translation: It's definitely an effective advertisement.

korean: 현재 저희는 남성 전립선 암 환자의 유전자 발현을 바꿀 수 있다는 연구를 발표 준비 중입니다.
actual translation: Now we're also about to publish a study -- the first study showing you can change gene expression in men with prostate cancer.
Google translation: We are currently preparing to publish a study showing that we can change gene expression in male prostate cancer patients.

korean: 이것은 히트 맵이라는 것인데 오른쪽에 보이시는 여러가지 색들은 각각 다른 유전자를 나타냅니다.
actual translation: This is what's called a heat map -- and the different colors -- and along the side, on the right, are different genes.
Google translation: This is a heat map, and the different colors on the right represent different genes.

korean: 여기서 500개 이상의 유전자들이 더 나은 방향으로 변하는 것을 관찰할 수 있었습니다. 좋은 유전자들, 즉 질병을 억제하는 유전자들은 활성화 되고 질병을 유발하는 유전자들은 억제되는 것을 관찰한 것이죠.
actual translation: And we found that over 500 genes were favorably changed -- in effect, turning on the good genes, the disease-preventing genes, turning off the disease-promoting genes.
Google translation: Here, more than 500 genes were observed to change for the better. We observed that good genes, that is, genes that suppress diseases, are activated and genes that cause diseases are suppressed.

korean: 이 발견들은 많은 사람들에게 희망과 선택의 기회를 준다는 점에서 매우 의미있는 것이라고 생각합니다.
actual translation: And so these findings I think are really very powerful, giving many people new hope and new choices.
Google translation: I think these discoveries are very meaningful in that they give hope and choice to many people.

korean: Navigenix, DNA Direct, 그리고 23andMe처럼 어떤 회사들은 고객들에게 유전자 프로필을 제공하기도 합니다. 때문에 일부 사람들은 내 유전자가 이런데 그럼 그것에 대해 도대체 뭘 어떻게 할 수 있는지 고민하기도 하죠.
actual translation: And companies like Navigenics and DNA Direct and 23andMe, that are giving you your genetic profiles, are giving some people a sense of, "Gosh, well, what can I do about it?"
Google translation: Some companies, such as Navigenix, DNA Direct, and 23andMe, offer genetic profiles to their customers. Because of this, some people wonder if their genes are like this and what on earth they can do about it.

korean: 유전자는 우리의 운명을 결정하지 않습니다. 물론 유전자는 우리가 타고난 고유의 성질이지만 앞서 말한 변화들을 실행한다면 그렇게 하지 않는 경우와 달리 우리는 유전자가 발현되는 방식에 영향을 줄 수 있습니다.
actual translation: Well, our genes are not our fate, and if we make these changes -- they're a predisposition -- but if we make bigger changes than we might have made otherwise, we can actually change how our genes are expressed.
Google translation: Genes do not determine our fate. Of course, genes are something we are born with, but if we make the changes mentioned above, we can influence the way our genes are expressed, unlike if we don't do so.

korean: 감사합니다.
actual translation: Thank you.
Google translation: thank you

korean: 저는 4년전에 여기에서 디자인과 행복의 관계를 이야기 했습니다.
actual translation: I was here about four years ago, talking about the relationship of design and happiness.
Google translation: I talked about the relationship between design and happiness here four years ago.

korean: 이야기가 끝날 때쯤 제목 밑으로 리스트를 보여줬는데
actual translation: At the very end of it, I showed a list under that title.
Google translation: At the end of the story, I showed a list under the title.

korean: 이 후 그 중에 배운 것은 거의 없었습니다. 그래도 그때부터 모든 것을 프로젝트로 진행했습니다.
actual translation: I learned very few things in addition since -- but made a whole number of them into projects since.
Google translation: After this I learned very little. Still, from then on, everything was done as a project.

korean: 이것은 스코틀랜드 도시에 세운 대형 원숭이입니다. "모든 사람들은 항상 자신들이 옳다고 생각한다."
actual translation: These are inflatable monkeys in every city "Everybody always thinks they are right."
Google translation: This is a large monkey erected in a Scottish city. “Everyone always thinks they are right.”

korean: 매체에서 이것들이 합쳐졌습니다.
actual translation: They were combined in the media.

korean: "약은 처음에는 재미있지만 나중에는 짐이 된다."
actual translation: "Drugs are fun in the beginning but become a drag later on."

korean: 우리는 변화하는 매체를 사용하고 있습니다.
actual translation: We're doing changing media.

korean: 이것은 관람자를 인식하는 영상입니다. 사람들이 지나가면서
actual translation: This is a projection that can see the viewer as the viewer walks by.
Google translation: This is a video that recognizes the viewer. As people pass by

korean: 어쩔 수 없이 거미줄을 찢습니다.
actual translation: You can't help but actually ripping that spider web apart.

korean: 이 모든 것들이 그래픽 디자인의 일부입니다.
actual translation: All of these things are pieces of graphic design.

korean: 우리는 고객을 위해 디자인하고
actual translation: We do them for our clients.

korean: 작품들은 고객이 의뢰한 것들입니다.

korean: 저는 결코 제 돈으로 이런 설치물을 만들거나, 이런 광고판 사용나 제작을 위해 돈을 쓰지 않습니다. 그래서 작품에는 항상 고객들이 있습니다.
actual translation: I would never have the money to actually pay for the installment or pay for all the billboards or the production of these, so there's always a client attached to them.

actual translation: These are 65,000 coat hangers in a street that's lined with fashion stores.

korean: "걱정은 아무것도 해결하지 않는다."
actual translation: "Worrying solves nothing."

korean: "돈은 나를 행복하게 해주지 않는다." 처음에는 양면 페이지 광고로 잡지에 나갔습니다.
actual translation: "Money does not make me happy" appeared first as double-page spreads in a magazine.
Google translation: “Money doesn’t make me happy.” It first appeared in magazines as a double-page advertisement.

korean: 인쇄업체가 파일을 잃어버렸는데, 우리에게 말하지 않았죠.
actual translation: The printer lost the file, didn't tell us.
Google translation: The printer lost the file and didn't tell us.

korean: 제가 잡지를 받았을 때 12장의 페이지 였는데
actual translation: When the magazine -- actually, when I got the subscription -- it was 12 following pages.
Google translation: When I received the magazine, it had 12 pages.

korean: "돈은 나를 정말로 정말로 행복하게 해준다." 였어요.
actual translation: It said, "Money does does make me happy."
Google translation: “Money makes me really, really happy.” It was.

korean: 그래서 미안함을 느낀 오스트리아에 있는 제 친구가 린츠의 가장 큰 카지노 주인에게 말하여 그의 빌딩에 이 작품을 덮을 수 있도록 해줬죠.
actual translation: And a friend of mine in Austria felt so sorry for me that he talked the largest casino owner in Linz into letting us wrap his building.

korean: 건물 정면에 "돈은" 이라고 써져 있고 옆면에는 "나를 행복하게 하지 않는다."라고 써 있죠.
actual translation: It just says "Money," and if you look down the side street, it says, "does not make me happy."
Google translation: On the facade it says "Money doesn't make me happy" and on the side it says "Money doesn't make me happy."

korean: 지난주 뉴욕에서는 쇼가 있었습니다.
actual translation: We had a show that just came down last week in New York.
Google translation: There was a show in New York last week.

korean: 창문에 지속적으로 김을 내고 매시간 다른 디자이너가 와서 사진과 같이 그들이 배운것들을 뿌옇게 된 창문에 썼습니다.
actual translation: We steamed up the windows permanently, and every hour we had a different designer come in and write these things that they've learned into the steam in the window.
Google translation: The windows were continuously steamed, and every hour a different designer came and wrote what they had learned on the fogged windows, as shown in the photos.

actual translation: Everybody participated -- Milton Glaser, Massimo Vignelli.

korean: 싱가폴은 꽤 논의의 대상이었습니다.
actual translation: Singapore was quite in discussion.
Google translation: Singapore has been the subject of quite a bit of discussion.

korean: 여기는 우리가 촬영한 작은 장소입니다. 싱가폴의 거대한 점보트론에 영상이 전시되었습니다.
actual translation: This is a little spot that we filmed there that's to be displayed on the large JumboTrons in Singapore.
Google translation: This is a small location where we filmed. The video was displayed on a giant jumbotron in Singapore.

korean: 제가 이 작품을 소중히 여기는 이유는 이 모든 감정들, 조금은 평범하고, 조금은 더 심오한 모든 것들이 제 일기장에서 가져온 것이기 때문입니다.
actual translation: And, of course, it's one that's dear to my heart, because all of these sentiments -- some banal, some a bit more profound -- all originally had come out of my diary.
Google translation: The reason I cherish this work is because all these emotions, some mundane, some more profound, were taken from my diary.

korean: 저는 종종 일기장을 열어보고 내가 어떤 상황에서 무엇이 변하기를 바랬었는지 확인합니다.
actual translation: And I do go often into the diary and check if I wanted to change something about the situation.
Google translation: I often open my journal to see what I wanted to change about a situation.

korean: 만약 오랜시간동안 원한다면 저는 실제로 그것에 관한 무엇인가를 합니다.
actual translation: If it's -- see it for a long enough time, I actually do something about it.

korean: 마지막은 광고판입니다.
actual translation: And the very last one is a billboard.

actual translation: This is our roof in New York, the roof of the studio.

korean: 신문용지와 신문용지 위에 스텐실을 놓았습니다.
actual translation: This is newsprint plus stencils that lie on the newsprint.
Google translation: I placed the stencil on newsprint and newsprint.

korean: 우리는 신문용지와 스텐실을 태양아래 놓습니다.
actual translation: We let that lie around in the sun.

korean: 여러분도 알다시피, 신문용지는 태양 아래에서 상당히 노랗게 됩니다.
actual translation: As you all know, newsprint yellows significantly in the sun.
Google translation: As you know, newsprint turns quite yellow in the sun.

korean: 일주일 후에 우리는 스텐실과 나뭇잎을 떼어내고 신문용지를 리스본에 태양이 내리쬐는 장소로 옮겼습니다. 그래서 첫날 광고판에는 이렇게 쓰였습니다. "불평은 바보짓이다. 행동하거나 잊어라."
actual translation: After a week, we took the stencils and the leaves off, shipped the newsprints to Lisbon to a very sunny spot, so on day one the billboard said, "Complaining is silly. Either act or forget."
Google translation: After a week we removed the stencils and leaves and moved the newsprint to a sunny spot in Lisbon. So on the first day, this was written on the billboard: “Complaining is stupid. Act or forget.”

korean: 3일 후에 작품은 사라졌고 일주일 후에는 어느곳에도 더이상 불평은 없었습니다.
actual translation: Three days later it faded, and a week later, no more complaining anywhere.
Google translation: After 3 days the work was gone and after a week there were no more complaints anywhere.

korean: 감사합니다.
actual translation: Thank you so much.

korean: 50년 전 구소련에서 여러 명의 엔지니어들이 황량한 시골 지방에서 엄청난 작업을 시작했습니다.
actual translation: Fifty years ago in the old Soviet Union, a team of engineers was secretly moving a large object through a desolate countryside.
Google translation: Fifty years ago in the former Soviet Union, a group of engineers began a monumental task in a barren countryside.

korean: 그들은 그 작업을 통해서 우주를 처음으로 정복함으로써 세계 모든 사람들의 마음을 사로잡기를 희망했습니다.
actual translation: With it, they were hoping to capture the minds of people everywhere by being the first to conquer outer space.
Google translation: Through their work, they hoped to conquer the hearts of people all over the world by being the first to conquer space.

korean: 로켓은 거대했습니다.
actual translation: The rocket was huge.
Google translation: The rocket was huge.

korean: 그리고 로켓의 앞부분에는 두 개의 라디오가 들어간 은으로 만들어진 공을 탑재했습니다.
actual translation: And packed in its nose was a silver ball with two radios inside.
Google translation: And the front of the rocket was equipped with a silver ball containing two radios.

korean: 1957년 10월 4일에 로켓을 발사했습니다.
